content: Survival function estimation, commonly used in medical analytics, faces privacy concerns due to sensitive patient data leakage. A novel differentially private estimator is proposed, extending to confidence intervals and test statistics without extra privacy budget. The method is validated on clinical datasets, showing good utility and strong privacy guarantees. The survival function estimates from patient data can lead to sensitive information disclosure, posing privacy risks. This function is used in various fields like economics, engineering, and healthcare. Protecting personal healthcare information is crucial, as violations can result in severe penalties. In the healthcare domain, information leakage is a serious issue with severe penalties. The focus of this study is on estimating the survival function using the Kaplan-Meier's non-parametric method, which is widely used in clinical research. There is a lack of models providing formal privacy guarantees for this method, with only one related work by Nguyên & Hui (2017). The study focuses on estimating the survival function using the Kaplan-Meier method in healthcare. Existing related work by Nguyên & Hui (2017) is limited to multivariate regression models and cannot provide differential privacy. Generative models like GANs could be used for this purpose but may not generalize well for small sample sizes and constrained data dimensions. The proposed method is the first to offer differential privacy for survival function estimation. The proposed method offers differential privacy for estimating the survival function based on the Kaplan-Meier method. It extends to provide private confidence intervals and test statistics without extra privacy cost. The method is also applicable for estimating the competing risk cumulative incidence function in clinical research. Empirical evidence from nine clinical datasets shows good utility and strong privacy guarantees. The method is released as an R package for easy accessibility.
